bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to John J. Moran, August 30, 1937

div1.p: Andrus relates his experiences as a yellow fever volunteer and criticizes Kissinger's conduct. He wants to know if other volunteers have spinal difficulties and includes a plan of the Columbia Barracks laboratory.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to John J. Moran, August 30, 1937
div1.opener:
J.H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
8-30-37
Captain John J. Moran,
% Cia. Sunoco de Cuba, S. A.
Avenida Menocal No. 102-A,
Havana, Cuba.
Dear Captain:
div1.p:
Was delighted to receive your very interesting letter and
cannot tell you how sincerely I regret that you did not
look me up when you were in Philadelphia. As I recall,
The Sun Co's. offices are on Walnut, above sixteenth, if
that is right we were only about fifteen minutes apart.

Used to know Mr. J. Howard Pew, also Mr. Leister, of your
Company. From 1910 until 1932 was Advertising Manager
of The R. M. Hollingshead Co. * Whiz Auto Chemicals * and
my Company have, for years, bought heavily from yours.

Was “listening in” the evening you were “on” with Lowell
Thomas and was much pleased with your remarks. What
you had to say was a refreshing change from the “me and
Walter Reed” attitude assumed by Kissinger.

I agree with you that Kissinger's thirst for publicity,
his apparent willingness to capitalize the part he took
and the manifest egotism of his utterances have a decided
tendency to cheapen all of us.

It is not surprising that you do not remember me as my
part was very obscure. When Major Reed and Lieutenant
Carroll moved to Cuba they brought with them - from the
Army Medical College - Steward Neal and a private of the
Hospital Corps.

Shortly after Dr. Lazear's death they took up quarters at
Columbia Barracks and the enlistment of the Corps man
expired. I was detailed to take his place. I was
scrub lady, keeper of the zoo - two monkeys and a lot of
guinea pigs - and mosquito hunter and breeder.

This must have been in November, 1900. Unfortunately,
I did not keep a record. The laboratory in which I
worked was the shack which had been the operating room
when the hospital was under canvas. In it Major Reed
and Lieut. Carroll had their microscopes and - ever on
the hunt for the elusive y. f. bacillus - they spent many
hours over their microscopes.
Page 2.

Much of the work of the Commission was planned by these
two, in the laboratory, and they paid no more attention
to me than to any other article of furniture.

Then, one morning, the Major was all steamed up because
one of his volunteers had suffered a change of heart and
knocked his schedule of experiments galley west.

Forbes had the fever and had reached the stage when they
wanted to innoculate another with his blood. The
Major told Lieut. Carroll he would take it. The Lieut.
was horrified and spent the day trying to argue the Major
out of the idea on the ground that the Major's age, and
the fact that he was run down by a recent illness, would
make his innoculation very hazardous.

I listened to all that and was afraid to do what seemed
the obvious thing. I had nursed y. f. at Guanajay,
had seen two men die and others critically ill with it,
and didn't want any in mine.
Next morning they were still at it. I volunteered.

After my recovery I went on a two months furlough and,
upon my returm, was assigned to other duty. It seems
to me that the man who took my place - when I was innoc-
ulated - was named Springer, but am not certain.

Please pardon me for being so voluminous - it is just
between we guinea pigs - and, while I had no intention
of going into all that I'll let it stand.

Perhaps all this was brought on you by your suggestion
that I know how Kissinger came to volunteer. I do
not - but would like awfully well to know. (With a
hint as broad as that don't you think it is rather up
to you?)

One of the reasons I wanted to get in touch with all my
fellow guinea pigs was to ascertain if any others have
had spinal trouble similar to mine. Was at Walter
Reed Hospital from May 13, until Oct. 6, 1932 and the
medicos there diagonsed my trouble as syringomyelia.
My son, a graduate of Hahnemann Medical College, does
not agree. He says “spinal arthritis”.

I have been bedfast since March, 1932, and am told that
I can never walk again. Have a large, airy room,
equipped with gadgets such as telephone, radio, hospital
bed, aa cabinet to hold the things I need at hand, an
electricbfan and even a typewriter with which to annoy
my friends.
Page 3.

I assume that your occupation of the laboratory was after
my innoculation - Jan. 28, 1901. (And just to keep
thatbfrom sounding foolish there is doubt in my mind as
to whether you mean the same laboratory that I do,)

Here is the one I mean:
H
C F G
B
E
D
A
To wards of
post hospital
Path to officers'
quarters - - -

list.item: A, B, D and E - in main room of laboratory.
A - Major Reed's Microscope - on wide shelf - counter high.
C - Quarters of Hospital Steward Neal
E - Counter holding more jars, paraffine shaver, etc.
F - Shelves in small room - test tubes of cultures, incubator.
G - Shelves and counter holding supplies and two monkey cages.
H - Small addition in which guinea pigs were housed.

div1.p: Unless I stop you will never dare write me again.

If you come to Philadelphia again please make it a point
to visit me. I am but two blocks from Walt Whitman Hotel,
which is first bus or train stop after crossing bridge.
With kindest regards and best wishes for your future,
